name: "Unwanted": Refugees, Asylum Seekers, and Patterns of Global Migration
base_name: "Unwanted": Refugees, Asylum Seekers, and Patterns of Global Migration
long_desc: What is home What does it mean to belong What does it mean to be mobile Is mobility a privilege or a curse How do experiences of migration, exile, and displacement shift ones understanding of home This course examines the modern patterns of mobility and displacement, with a focus on the US and Europe at particular moments during the 19th,the 20th, and 21st centuries. We will focus on several case studies to illustrate broader concepts the connection between the formation of nationstates and the rise of exclusionary citizenship the emergence of 20thcentury modern legal concepts such as refugee and asylum the influence of the Cold War on the immigration policies in the US and the criminalization of bordercrossing.

custom_fields.goals: Critical thinking skillsAnalytical reading skillsAnalytical writing Knowledge of key issues in scholarship regarding migration, with a special focus on the US and Europe
custom_fields.key_topics: Patterns and policies of migration, mobility, and displacement, with a particular focus on 20th and early 21st century Europe and the US.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
1.	Attendance and participation in class discussion
2.	Preparation of discussion questions on a course reading
3.	One critical assessment of a book assigned for the course (3-4 pages)
4.	Final project:
a.	In-class presentation of a group project on specific sites and cases of mass migration in today's world (Greece, Spain, the Mexico-US border, etc. )
+ b. One 3-4 pages written report on the research project (discussion of methodology and specific sources, and a critical assessment of the site/case-study)
custom_fields.relevance: Via critical discussions of anthropological and historic analyses of migration, students will learn about patterns and policies of migration, mobility, and displacement, with a particular focus on 20th and early 21st century Europe and the US.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Lectures, books, documentaries, and shorter texts uploaded as pdfs on Canvas.
